nodes.text: Changing how students are allocated to colleges can substantially reduce parental-income segregation across colleges and increase intergenerational income mobility in the United States

Method: constructed near-complete college-level statistics by linking deidentified federal tax records, Department of Education records (1098-T and Pell/NSLDS), College Board and ACT data for nearly all U.S. college students (1999–2013) and measured parent incomes (mean ages 15–19) and child earnings (ages 32–34)
Claim: Parental-income segregation across colleges is very high, with elite private colleges heavily overrepresented by top-income families

Claim: Differences in earnings between children from low- and high-income families are much smaller within the same college than across colleges, implying between-college sorting accounts for much of national parent-child persistence

Evidence: Ivy-Plus colleges: 14.5% of students from top 1% vs 3.8% from bottom quintile; children from top 1% are 77 times more likely to attend Ivy-Plus than bottom quintile; aggregate across tiers shows large concentration at selective institutions

Evidence: National unconditional rank-rank slope ~0.288, but controlling for college fixed effects reduces slope to ~0.139; within-college rank-rank slopes are much smaller (e.g., ~0.065 at elite colleges), showing within-college parent-child persistence is smaller

Claim: Income segregation across colleges is about as large as segregation across childhood neighborhoods (ZIP code exposure indices similar), and most segregation is not explained by geographic sourcing alone

Evidence: For children with bottom-quintile parents, percent of college peers from top quintile (22.5%) is similar to percent of childhood ZIP-code peers from top quintile; locally normed adjustments correlate strongly (0.77) with raw college segregation measures

Claim: There is substantial heterogeneity across colleges in student earnings outcomes and mobility; some mid-tier public colleges combine high shares of low-income students with relatively strong earnings outcomes (high mobility rates), while Ivy-Plus colleges have very high upper-tail (top 1%) outcomes

Evidence: Mobility-rate examples: Cal State LA mobility ~9.9% (bottom-to-top quintile), CUNY average ~7.2%; Ivy-Plus mean top-quintile outcome ~58% but bottom-quintile share only 3.8%; Ivy-Plus dominate top-1% outcomes (enrollment-weighted mean top-1% outcome 12.8%)

Claim: Differences in parental income distributions across colleges are partly explained by differences in academic preparation (SAT/ACT) but large residual differences remain due to application/admission/matriculation choices conditional on test scores

Evidence: Test-score facts: very few high-scoring students are low-income—only about 3.7% of college-goers with SAT/ACT >=1300 come from bottom quintile (imputed for missing scores and validated in states with near-universal testing)

Method / Counterfactuals: simulated two reallocations—(A) income-neutral allocation that randomizes college slots conditional on SAT/ACT, state, and race (removes income variation in enrollment among equal-score students) and (B) need-affirmative allocation that adds test-score equivalent preferences to lower-income students (e.g., +160 SAT pts for bottom quintile, linearly declining for higher quintiles)

Result (income-neutral): income-neutral allocation would substantially reduce segregation overall (closes ~64% of the gap in exposure for bottom-quintile students vs full random) and would narrow the top-quintile outcome gap between children of high- vs low-income parents by ~15% assuming 80% of college differences are causal

Result (need-affirmative): need-affirmative allocations (e.g., 160-point bottom-quintile advantage) would essentially eliminate parental-income differences across college tiers and, under the baseline 80% causal assumption, could reduce intergenerational income persistence among college students by about 25% (larger reductions in upper-tail gaps)

Assumption & Limitation: baseline simulations assume 80% of cross-college differences in earnings conditional on SAT/ACT, race, and parent income are causal and that colleges' causal effects remain unchanged under reallocation; results are highly sensitive to this causal-share assumption and ignore possible peer-composition or equilibrium effects
